pt: {sc}proficient{/sc} {sc}adept{/sc} {sc}skilled{/sc} {sc}skillful{/sc} {sc}expert{/sc} mean having great knowledge and experience in a trade or profession. {sc}proficient{/sc} implies a thorough competence derived from training and practice.
{sc}adept{/sc} implies special aptitude as well as proficiency.
{sc}skillful{/sc} implies individual dexterity in execution or performance.
{sc}expert{/sc} implies extraordinary proficiency and often connotes knowledge as well as technical skill.

quotes.t: Madison, Jefferson's lifelong friend, collaborator, and political ally, was quizzical and skeptical. His mind was less capacious and less elevated than Jefferson's, but more … original, and instinctively contrary. Less learned than Jefferson, his verbal skills inferior, he was almost pedantically alert to inner complications, and so, though less {qword}adept{/qword} a politician, he was more consistent.

et: borrowed from New Latin {it}adeptus{/it} "one who has attained a high degree of proficiency (as in alchemy or hermetic philosophy)," going back to Latin, "having attained," past participle of {it}adipīscī{/it} "to arrive at, attain," from {it}ad-{/it} {et_link|ad-|ad-} + {it}apīscī{/it} "to seize hold of, obtain," perhaps an inchoative derivative from the base of {it}apere{/it} "to join" {ma}{mat|apt:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: a highly skilled or well-trained individual : expert
